as regards those of the other layer, that one of the connecting stolons
from which each segment arises, will pass into the alternating cell of the upper
layer and the other into that of the lower, This arrangement may
present itself as one of the modes of transition from the simpler to
the more complex type, as is shown in Plate VII Fig 8; the columns<s>ar</s>
being disposed to subdivide transversely when they attain a
considerable length, and the annular canal becoming double;
whilst in zones more distant from the centre the two layers
are separated by the interposition of the intermediate
stratum. Sometimes, however, the disk continues to increase
and attains a considerable size on this duplex type; and
its edge then presents two rows of rounded prominences with
pores between them, those of the upper and lower rows
alternating with each other as is well seen in the vertical plate
of the monstrosity represented in Plate XII Fig6. It is on a disk
of this type, that Prof Ehrenberg has founded his genus <u>Amphisorus</u>,
which I cannot regard as <s>not</s> even specifically distinct from
the ordinary Orbitolite. <s>The peculiar concentric aspect of the
surface (Plate X Fig.11) on which D'Orbigny has founded his genus</s>
